div.p: Distance Learning for high school and middle school students begins April 10. Distance Learning for elementary students begins April 13. Aprendizaje a Distancia para estudiantes de secundaria y preparatoria comienza 10 de abril. Aprendizaje a Distancia para estudiantes de primaria comienza 13 de abril.

div.p: For those who are unable to access Wi-Fi to connect remotely or work from home, ComcastÂ is offering two free months of internet service to qualifying families. Details can be found here:Â https://www.internetessentials.com/covid19

Para aquellos que no pueden acceder a Wi-Fi para conectarse de forma remota o trabajar desde casa,Â ComcastÂ ofrece dos meses gratis de servicio de Internet a familias que califican. Los detalles se pueden encontrar aquÃ­:Â https://www.internetessentials.com/covid19

p.span: The transition to Distance Learning for All is a big one. We are implementing an educational model that is new for most staff. Each of us is doing all that we can to develop systems and structures to support students during this unparalleled challenge in our community, nation, and world. Distance Learning must focus on connection first.

Teachers are taking attendance to track participation in distance learning. Our focus is to ensure our students are connecting with their teachers and their classroom communities. Teachers and support staff are tasked with reaching out to directly to students who are not participating in distance learning opportunities

p.b: Grading for Students in High School

i.span: â€œAs a means to promote learning and award credit, all districts in Oregon shall move from letter grades to Pass/Incomplete (or local equivalent) for students enrolled in high school courses for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. We must consider the severe impact of the pandemic on students and families across the state and take steps that prioritize ongoing learning while safeguarding against unintended consequences as students pursue postsecondary opportunities.â€
Oregon Department of Education, Distance Learning for All

p.b: Grading will not be based on participation during live events.Â

p.span: Gradebook will continue to be used to record grades as it is a tool both students and families are familiar with using. All graded work will be formative and based on student proficiency. Teachers will provide targeted feedback to help students develop a better understanding of content or a specific skill, and adjust instruction to help students meet proficiency.Â
Grading that uses the following guidelines will be utilized:

li.span: Z- Student did not turn in assignment
T- Student turned in assignment but it is not graded yet
1- Student does not YET show proficiencyÂ
2- Student has demonstrated proficiency

p.b: Grading for Students in Middle School

p.span: All classes will be pass or no pass. Grades for fourth quarter in middle school will be based on proficiency shown in the last quarterÂ of the 2019/2020 academic year.
Â

p.b: Grading will not be based on participation during live events.Â

p.span: Gradebook will continue to be used to record grades as it is a tool both students and families are familiar with using. All graded work will be formative and based on student proficiency. Teachers will provide targeted feedback to help students develop a better understanding of content or a specific skill, and adjust instruction to help students meet proficiency.Â
Grading that uses the following guidelines will be utilized:

li.span: Z- Student did not turn in assignment
T- Student turned in assignment but it is not graded yet
1- Student does not YET show proficiencyÂ
2- Student has demonstrated proficiency

p.b: Grading for Students in Elementary School

p.span: Challenges associated with measurement of essential learning and grading in our distance learning context may result in highly variable, subjective, and potentially unfair grading practices. To create continuity of learning, while mitigating for potential grading risks, the following reporting and grading practices are required:Â

li.span: District-wide application of end-of-year reporting practices, including a report card (or district equivalent) for every student.Â
District-wide Pass or Incomplete (or local equivalent) grading system on the final 2019- 2020 report card. Districts shall not use letter grades or fail students.
Standards Based reporting (Levels 1 â€“ 4) will be replaced with Incomplete (Level 1) or Pass (Levels 2-4)

i.span: â€“ Oregon Department of Education, Distance Learning for All

p.b: Grading will not be based on participation during live events.Â

p.span: Student promotion to the next grade level shall not be based on performance during the period of school closure; no child shall be held back or retained due to any impacts of extended school closure.Â

High school principals, teachers, and student leaders are working on plans to celebrate the Class of 2020 since social distancing requirements will not allow us to have traditional graduation ceremonies at each high school. Graduation will take place the week of June 5. Students and families will be notified as soon as graduation plans have been finalized.

If you donâ€™t have regular internet access at home, please let your childâ€™s teacher know so they can provide paper materials. We have limited Wi-Fi access points available. Please contact your school principal to access.

In addition, our district has created a free internet access area in the Linus Pauling Middle School north parking lot, located at 1111 NW Cleveland Avenue. Please enter the parking lot from NW Highland Drive.Â Â

Wi-Fi is available from 7 am â€“ 10 pm, 7 days a week. Student devices will automatically login through the district filter at this location. Parent/guardian non-district devices can also login to the Corvallis School District Wi-Fi network using the password Education.

li.span: If you come to the area by car, please plan to remain in your vehicle.
If you are not in a vehicle, please practice safe physical distancing (6 feet or more) from others.

p.span: Internet connectivity on all student devices (for example iPad or Chromebook)Â is always routed through the school districtâ€™s internet filter ensuring student privacy and grade-level appropriate content. While the district has the ability to monitor downloaded apps, it does not have the ability to view content within apps. There are no specific home wi-fi speed requirements for our learning platforms.

That said, no filter is perfect.Â Additionally, some categories that are normally blocked, such as streaming media, have been opened for the spring to permit for the use of more remote schooling resources.Â For these reasons, we strongly suggest that you set expectations and goals with your students for their learning time, and
p.b: closely monitor how they are spending this time
p.span: .Â Set up a learning space near where adults are working (or where they can easily pop out and see screens) and hold kids and teens accountable.Â Is this easy?Â Those of us with school aged kids who are navigating this same situation can emphatically say â€œNO!â€ but also realize the importance of setting rules and expectations early, and holding both ourselves and our children to them.Â Weâ€™re all in this together, and doing our best to navigate a difficult time.
Personal belongings pick up are taking place at individual schools. Please contact your childâ€™s school if you have questions.
Student transfer requests may be made through an online process from May 18 â€“ 31 for the 2020-21 school year. The online form will be available on the web starting May 18. Visit the
for more information.Â

div.h3: School to Home Communication and Office Hours (to reach staff)

p.span: Classroom teachers, specialists, counselors, and others are committed to regular outreach and personal communication with students. Google Classroom, SeeSaw, emails, and phone calls are all tools that we may use to connect to promote communication. If you receive a phone call from a (541) 286- phone number, please answer it as it will be a staff member from your childâ€™s school.

li.span: Teachers continue to be available to email if you have questions or concerns.
Staff members have designated times, â€œoffice hoursâ€ throughout the school day for students to connect directly with teachers.Â Â

As we work through these uncertain times, know that we approach this work collaboratively.Â Staff, too, are adapting to a new normal for themselves in working from home, setting boundaries, taking care of family members, and coming to terms with not being back in school for the rest of the year. We ask that you respect boundaries of communication frequency and times, so staff can be prepared to support your children.Â We ask that you hold grace, patience, and understanding for your teachers and children as we adapt to this extended school building closure.Â

p.span: The following are tools that teachers and school staff might be using to communicate with students and families.Â Please find resources for each tool, along with a description of how the tool could be used, below.

div.h3: Digital Classrooms: Google Classroom and Seesaw

p.span: These programs enable our teachers to provide and deliver content to students, and for students to respond to that content and interact with teachers and peers. These tools were reintroduced to teachers through professional learning opportunities. We want to ensure safe use of digital platforms and to make sure teachers can provide clear expectations to students for the tools being used.

li.span: Google Meet and Zoom are the platforms weâ€™ve chosen to use for live interaction between students and teachers.Â Â
Google Chat and student emails (Gr 6-12 only) are tools students can use to communicate with teachers and classmates.Â Â

p.span: Google Classroom is a web-based learning environment. When logged into Google Classroom, students can collaborate with their peers and teachers. Google Classroom offers a digital safe space for students to view class announcements, access posted course content, view posted assignments, and turn in completed work. If your studentâ€™s teacher uses Google Classroom, you can view the daily assignments simply by looking at the Google Classroom app on your studentâ€™s device. Use the following support documents to get your student signed into Google Classroom:

Seesaw is a platform used primarily at the elementary level. Most students have the SeeSaw app on their iPad.Â If you cannot find it, please download the app from Self Service and check with your childâ€™s teacher for more information. Parents are frequently invited to join in from their own device; if so your childâ€™s teacher will send you instructions on how to do that. Learn more about SeeSaw:
Zoom is another meeting tool that may be used by teaching staff

div.h3: Technical support for Student iPads and Chromebooks

p.span: Family tech support is available! Please call the Tech Support Help Desk at 541-757-3911, Monday through Friday, 8 am to 5 pm.

Youâ€™re not alone in this, and we are here to support you! We appreciate you learning alongside us as we embark on this unique opportunity. Please contact your childâ€™sÂ teacher, counselor, or principal at any time with your questions.

p.b: Calificaciones para estudiantes en escuela primaria

p.span: Los desafÃ­os asociados con la mediciÃ³n del aprendizaje esencial y la calificaciÃ³n en nuestro contexto de aprendizaje a distancia pueden resultar en prÃ¡cticas de calificaciÃ³n altamente variables, subjetivas y potencialmente injustas. La graduaciÃ³n se llevarÃ¡ a cabo la semana del 5 de junio. Los estudiantes y las familias serÃ¡n notificados tan pronto como se hayan finalizado los planes de graduaciÃ³n.

Si no tiene acceso regular a Internet en casa, informe al maestro de su hijo para que pueda proporcionarle materiales en papel. Tenemos puntos de acceso Wi-Fi limitados disponibles. Por favor, pÃ³ngase en contacto con el director de su escuela para acceder.

AdemÃ¡s, nuestro distrito ha creado un Ã¡rea de acceso gratuito a Internet en el estacionamiento norte de la Escuela Secundaria Linus Pauling, ubicada en 1111 NW Cleveland Avenue. Ingrese al estacionamiento desde NW Highland Drive.

Los dispositivos de padres / tutores que no pertenecen al distrito tambiÃ©n pueden iniciar sesiÃ³n en la red Wi-Fi del Distrito Escolar de Corvallis utilizando la contraseÃ±a: EducaciÃ³n.

li.span: Si llega al Ã¡rea en automÃ³vil, por favor quÃ©dese en el vehÃ­culo.
Si no llega en un vehÃ­culo, por favor practique distanciamiento social ( 2 metros o mÃ¡s).

p.span: La conectividad a Internet en todos los dispositivos de los estudiantes (por ejemplo, iPad o Chromebook) siempre se enruta a travÃ©s del filtro de Internet del distrito escolar que garantiza la privacidad de los estudiantes, asÃ­ como el contenido apropiado para el nivel de grado. Si bien el distrito tiene la capacidad de monitorear las aplicaciones descargadas, no tiene la capacidad de ver el contenido dentro de las aplicaciones. AdemÃ¡s, algunas categorÃ­as que normalmente estÃ¡n bloqueadas, como la transmisiÃ³n de medios, se han abierto durante la primavera para permitir el uso de mÃ¡s recursos escolares remotos. Por estas razones, le recomendamos que establezca expectativas y objetivos con sus estudiantes para su tiempo de aprendizaje, y que supervise de cerca cÃ³mo estÃ¡n pasando este tiempo. Todos estamos juntos en esto y hacemos todo lo posible para navegar en un momento difÃ­cil.
Las pertenencias personales se recogen en cada escuela de manera individual. ComunÃ­quese con la escuela de su hijo si tiene alguna pregunta.

p.span: Estos programas permiten a nuestros maestros proporcionar y entregar contenido a los estudiantes, y a los estudiantes responder a ese contenido e interactÃºar con maestros y compaÃ±eros. li.span: Google Meet y Zoom son las plataformas que elegimos usar para la interacciÃ³n en vivo entre estudiantes y maestros
